Award.AbstractNarration:
This project in the field of algebraic geometry concerns aspects of valuation theory. Valuations appear naturally in many branches of mathematics. Spaces of valuations, as a whole, capture important information, for example in connection with the problem of resolution of singularities. There are many natural ways of looking at valuations and packaging them into spaces, and each provides useful tools for studying algebraic varieties. The focus of the proposed research is on two valuation spaces: the space of arcs and the Berkovich analytification of an algebraic variety. These spaces come equipped with interesting structure and can be used to answer important mathematical questions.

Nash investigated the space of arcs in connection to singularities; the same space serves as the underlying space in motivic integration, and has been applied to study invariants of singularities in the minimal model program. Berkovich's non-Archimedean geometry has been used in a variety of contexts, from p-adic geometry to dynamics, geometric group theory, mirror symmetry, and tropical geometry, and most recently in birational geometry. Many interesting questions about the structure of these spaces remain open, and a better understanding of their geometry will lead to new applications. One specific goal of this project is to study the local rings on the arc space of a variety, a problem motivated by Shokurov's semicontinuity conjecture on minimal log discrepancies and therefore, indirectly, by the conjecture on termination of flips, one of the missing steps in the minimal model program. Another objective proposes a new point of view on motivic integration where Berkovich spaces are used in place of arc spaces. The project also addresses some questions about links of isolated singularities, their contact structure, and their CR structure. While these are apparently unrelated questions, there is an underlying connection between the contact structure of a link and valuation theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In regards to intellectual merits, the research carried out under this grant has led to new discoveries in the field of algebraic geometry that contribute to our understanding of several aspects regarding the structure of the singularities of algebraic varieties.

One area of investigation concerns the structure of arc spaces of algebraic varieties. These spaces have been used to define string theoretic invariants of singular Calabi-Yau varieties and to study singularities in the minimal model program. In spite of being an infinite dimensional object, it was shown by Drinfeld, Grinberg, and Kazhdan that the singularities of the arc space at most points are finite dimensional. In collaboration with Chiu and Docampo, the PI has found a way of quantifying these singularities by extending to arbitrary local rings the notion of embedding codimension, a familiar notion in the Noetherian setting. The main result can be interpreted as saying that the singularities of the arc space are maximal at the arcs that are fully embedded in the singular locus of the underlying scheme, and progressively improve as one moves away from said locus.

In a different direction, the PI studied link-theoretic invariants of isolated singularities. A theorem of Mumford states that, on complex surfaces, any normal isolated singularity whose link is diffeomorphic to a sphere is actually a smooth point, and while this property fails in higher dimensions, McLean has shown that in dimension three the contact structure that the link inherits from its embedding in the variety suffices to characterize smooth points among normal isolated singularities. Using CR geometry, the PI found a new link-theoretic invariant of singularity that can be used to distinguish smooth points among normal isolated singularities of arbitrary dimension. The proof relies on a partial solution to the complex Plateau problem which improves upon and extends prior works of Du, Guo, and Yau.

In collaboration with Lau, the PI has developed a new theory of motivic integration on Berkovich spaces.  The approach maintains the same geometric flavor of the original definition of Kontsevich and yet is rich enough to reproduce some of the features of Cluckers and Loeser’s theory of constructible motivic functions, and flexible enough to apply to different settings, including working over valued fields as in the works of Loeser-Sebag and Hrushovski-Kazhdan. In another collaboration with Lau, the PI studied certain properties of embedding of varieties where the subvariety satisfies certain positivity conditions. The main results obtained in this direction include a Grothendieck-Lefschetz theorem for ample subvarieties, and make progress on a conjecture of Sommese from 1976 which states that under some conditions, morphisms defined on a smooth ample subvariety of a complex projective manifold extend to the ambient variety.

From the point of view of broader impacts, the PI has advised graduate and undergraduate students, has mentored postdocs, was a speaker in the Math Circle, and has been involved in other training activities in his role of co-director of an RTG grant. As chair of the Mathematics Education Committee, the PI has also been involved within the department’s pre-service and in-service teacher preparation program.
